metadata.title: National Collegiate Athletic Association v. Alston
metadata.caseName: National Collegiate Athletic Association v. Shawne Alston, et al.

court.name: Supreme Court of the United States

section.heading: Introduction
section.p: United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit -> Writ of <i>certiorari</i

section.heading: Factual background
section.p: In NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma, 468 U.S. 85 (1984), the Supreme Court struck down the NCAA’s television plan as violating antitrust law, but in so doing it held that the rules regarding eligibility standards for college athletes are subject to a different and less stringent analysis than other types of antitrust cases. Because of this lower standard, the NCAA has long argued that antitrust law permits them to restrict athlete compensation to promote competitive equity and to distinguish college athletics from professional sports.

Several Division 1 football and basketball players filed a lawsuit against the NCAA, arguing that its restrictions on “non-cash education-related benefits,” violated antitrust law under the Sherman Act. The district court found for the athletes, holding that the NCAA must allow for certain types of academic benefits, such as “computers, science equipment, musical instruments and other tangible items not included in the cost of attendance calculation but nonetheless related to the pursuit of academic studies.” However, the district court held that the NCAA may still limit cash or cash-equivalent awards for academic purposes. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit affirmed, recognizing the NCAA’s interest in “preserving amateurism,” but concluding nevertheless that its practices violated antitrust law.

section.heading: Questions Presented
section.p: Does the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA)’s prohibition on compensation for college athletes violate federal antitrust law?

section.heading: Holding / Conclusion
section.p: The NCAA’s rules restricting certain education-related benefits for student-athletes violate federal antitrust laws. Writing for a unanimous Court, Justice Neil Gorsuch upheld the trial court’s ruling. The Court affirmed that the traditional “rule of reason” standard was appropriate in this case and rejected the NCAA’s call for a more deferential standard. Because the student-athletes who brought the lawsuit did not appeal the Ninth Circuit’s ruling upholding the NCAA’s rules “untethered to education,” the Court did not pass judgment on that aspect of the case.

In affirming the Ninth Circuit’s ruling, the Court clarified that a prior statement made in the 1984 case NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma noting that the NCAA’s role in maintaining the “revered tradition of amateurism” was “entirely consistent with the goals of the Sherman Act” was not a shield against all challenges to compensation restrictions, as such rules were not even at issue in that case. Instead, there was nothing so unique about the NCAA or amateur sports to alter the traditional method of analysis applied to claims of antitrust violations.

In a concurring opinion, Justice Brett Kavanaugh noted that while other rules limiting student-athlete compensation unrelated to academics remain in place because they were not properly before the Court, this decision makes clear that the same traditional “rule of reason” analysis would apply. He concluded, “there are serious questions whether the NCAA’s remaining compensation rules can pass muster under ordinary rule of reason scrutiny.”

section.heading: Decision
section.p: The district court’s injunction pertaining to certain NCAA rules limiting the education-related benefits schools may make available to student-athletes is consistent with established antitrust principles.

QAPairsFiltered.caseName: National Collegiate Athletic Association v. Shawne Alston, et al.

Pair.Question: What specific category of benefits did the Division 1 football and basketball players successfully challenge as violating the Sherman Act?
Pair.Answer: The athletes successfully challenged the NCAA’s restrictions on **“non-cash education-related benefits”**.

Pair.Question: What was the central standard of antitrust review the Supreme Court affirmed as appropriate for this case, and whose call for a different standard did the Court reject?
Pair.Answer: The Court affirmed that the **traditional “rule of reason”** standard was appropriate in this case and rejected the **NCAA’s call for a more deferential standard**.

Pair.Question: What types of academic benefits did the District Court specifically require the NCAA to allow as a result of the injunction?
Pair.Answer: The District Court required the NCAA to allow for academic benefits such as **“computers, science equipment, musical instruments and other tangible items not included in the cost of attendance calculation but nonetheless related to the pursuit of academic studies”**.

Pair.Question: What was the scope limitation of the Supreme Court's ruling regarding NCAA compensation rules that are "untethered to education"?
Pair.Answer: The Court **did not pass judgment** on the NCAA’s rules **“untethered to education”** because the student-athletes who brought the lawsuit did not appeal the Ninth Circuit’s ruling upholding those specific rules.

Pair.Question: According to the District Court's original ruling, what forms of compensation for academic purposes did the NCAA still retain the authority to limit?
Pair.Answer: The District Court held that the NCAA **may still limit cash or cash-equivalent awards for academic purposes**.

Pair.Question: What prior Supreme Court case did the NCAA rely upon to argue for a less stringent antitrust analysis for eligibility standards, and in what year was that prior case decided?
Pair.Answer: The NCAA relied upon **NCAA v. Board of Regents of the University of Oklahoma**, which was decided in **1984** (468 U.S. 85).

Pair.Question: What was the significance of the 1984 *Board of Regents* case in terms of antitrust law application to the NCAA, even though the issue in *Alston* was different?
Pair.Answer: The Court clarified that the prior statement about the "revered tradition of amateurism" in the 1984 case was **not a shield against all compensation restrictions** because such rules were not even at issue in that case.

Pair.Question: What conclusion did Justice Kavanaugh reach in his concurring opinion regarding the NCAA’s remaining compensation rules that were not directly before the Court?
Pair.Answer: Justice Kavanaugh concluded that the same traditional "rule of reason" analysis would apply and that **"there are serious questions whether the NCAA’s remaining compensation rules can pass muster under ordinary rule of reason scrutiny"**.

Pair.Question: What specific interest did the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals recognize on the part of the NCAA when it affirmed the District Court’s ruling against the NCAA?
Pair.Answer: The Ninth Circuit recognized the NCAA’s interest in **“preserving amateurism,”** but nevertheless concluded that its practices violated antitrust law.

Pair.Question: What was the final outcome of the case in the Supreme Court, including the vote count and the identity of the justice who wrote the majority opinion?
Pair.Answer: The Supreme Court upheld the trial court’s injunction against the NCAA's restrictions on education-related benefits. The decision was **unanimous (9-0)** in favor of **Alston**, with Justice **Neil Gorsuch** writing the opinion of the Court.
